story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Sotheby’s sale raising&nbspfunds for food surplus charity The Felix Project will also feature&nbspwork by Tracey&nbspEmin,&nbspBridget Riley&nbspand&nbspAnish&nbspKapoorArtworks by Ai Weiwei, Tracey Emin and Anish Kapoor are among those to be featured in a Sotheby’s contemporary art auction next week to support The Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign.The sale, part of Sotheby’s Contemporary Art Day Auction that runs from 20 to 30 July, includes leading contemporary artists Bridget Riley, Mark Wallinger and Bob and Roberta Smith. All money raised from the auction will go to The Independent’s appeal partner, The Felix Project, London’s largest food surplus distribution charity. Our campaign has so far raised £7.5m towards our £10m goal which includes a pledge to open London’s largest community kitchen to tackle food poverty.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHighlights from the Sotheby’s Help the Hungry auction include a drawing from Tracey Emin, a series of three etchings by Anish Kapoor, Mark Wallinger’s “Ghost”, and Bob &amp Roberta Smith’s “We Have Only Got Each Other” placard.British-Nigerian artist Yinka Shonibare also joins the catalogue with his “Unstructured Icons - Aristocrat I” alongside a pair of polished steel reliefs by Michael Craig-Martin and a floral plate by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.   How to support our campaignSotheby’s senior director Oliver Barker said: “We are grateful to the artists who have generously contributed their works and we’re looking forward to channelling part of the excitement of our major sales in London this month into a cause which will provide food and comfort to the capital’s most vulnerable.”  Evgeny Lebedev, proprietor of The Independent, said: “We are delighted to be raising money with Sotheby’s and some of the world’s leading contemporary artists to help build London’s biggest community kitchen that will continue to feed those in need for years to come.”The Felix Project distributes nutritious food that would otherwise go to waste to 350 frontline charities, schools and holiday programmes in London.Founder Justin Byam Shaw said: “Although our food is surplus and donated to us and we have over 1,500 volunteers, our costs are still spiralling. “The coming unemployment crisis means we are in this for the long term. This new community kitchen will provide a high-quality meal for homeless Londoners, cooked by great chefs using surplus food.” Turner Prize-winning artist Mark Wallinger said: “I am delighted to contribute to help raise funds for The Felix Project, a fantastic charity that does such vital work in providing food for vulnerable people throughout London, work that is ever more necessary in our current crisis.”Sotheby’s Help The Hungry Auction will go live on 20 July and will run until 30 July.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: help the hungry campaign artwork auction ai weiwei tracey emin
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.&nbspWorks by Ai Weiwei, Tracey Emin and Bridget Riley feature in Sotheby’s sale for food surplus charity The Felix Project “We have only got each other.” What could be more true? At a time when Londoners from all walks of life are struggling due to the impact of coronavirus, the importance of love and care from others has been magnified tenfold.The phrase comes from a work made by the artist Bob &amp Roberta Smith – one of several fantastic lots in an auction kicking off today at sothebys to support The Independent’s Help the Hungry appeal.Over the past four months we have raised more than £7.5m for food redistribution charity The Felix Project – a cause for which we have pledged to raise £10m as well as to open central London’s largest community kitchen.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe auction is an opportunity to get your hands on works by some amazing artists – more likely to be seen on the walls of a museum than your living room. They can also be viewed at Sotheby’s, 34-35 New Bond Street.Ceramic has been a recurring motif for Ai Weiwei (a 1995 series of photographs showed him dropping a Han dynasty urn) and he has often used porcelain, for centuries a secret formula known only to Chinese makers. Flowers, too, are significant – when his passport was taken Ai put a bunch of fresh flowers in a bike basket outside his studio every day until he was able to travel freely. This small plate holds a great deal of meaning.Yinka Shonibare deconstructions of icons of western power couldn’t be more current. This elegant woodcut print, using vivid Batik textiles, transposes animal masks from Mali onto the faces of English aristocratic figures enriched off the back of colonisation and slavery. The patterns of textiles overlay the repeating patterns of power and show how history’s long fingers reach into our present.Unfailingly optimistic, Bob &amp Roberta Smith’s work is always a call to care. He’s known for his colourful and impassioned but peaceful slogans (“Make Art Not War” seems like a good standard to live by) and his advocacy of art as a tool for education and understanding. We Have Only Got Each Other quotes his late mother, the artist Deirdre Borlase, spoken in response to the isions revealed during the Brexit campaign — but its universal meaning is clear.I’m a sucker for a good drawing – I’ve always felt that even at 500-odd years distance, it’s the form that brings you closest to an artist the sweep of a human hand that has just left the page. After many years of deeply mining her own emotions and experiences in her work, Emin is an artist at the height of her powers. Her raw, almost agonisingly expressive draughtsmanship gets me every time and this little sketch nails the feeling of having a really good cry.These three etchings – a supremely generous donation from Anish Kapoor, more usually known for the interactive theatricality of his large-scale sculptures – exude a quiet drama. Their simplicity belies their seductiveness velvety and intense, they draw you in, never quite revealing their secrets.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Wallinger was inspired by X-rays of Old Masters, which he thinks of as akin to spirit photography: “The revelation of the invisible, supernatural life of a painting.”A reminder of the pre-lockdown era, when we were able to wander the Hayward Gallery and bathe in the sea of pulsating colour that was Riley’s superb exhibition. This screenprint is from a series that vibrates right off the paper (Tate owns an edition of Elongated Triangles 5, so you’ll be in good company if you get your hands on this one).The essence of things is what Michael Craig-Martin seeks in his work, and colour is part of seducing the viewer to really look at the objects that make up our world. These sculptural reliefs in polished steel come from a series that pays homage to designers and architects whose vision has shaped what we think of as “modern”. His departure came just days before the return of pupils to schools in England and Wales next week, a crucial part of the nation’s withdrawal from coronavirus lockdown which he had responsibility for overseeing.Education mandarin out as PM demands ‘fresh’ leadership Boris Johnson blames exams chaos on ‘mutant algorithm’'Fallback measures' being prepared in case Covid disrupts future examsOfqual boss resigns in wake of exams chaosHe is the fifth head of a government department to be ousted since Boris Johnson returned to office in December’s election with his top adviser Dominic Cummings intent on a shake-up of Whitehall to concentrate more power in the prime minister’s hands. Announcing his departure on Wednesday, the DFE made clear the decision to force him out had been made personally by Mr Johnson, who demanded “fresh official leadership” in the department.Former civil service chief Lord (Bob) Kerslake told Radio 4’s The World Tonight that his dismissal was “a complete disgrace”, adding: “I know Jonathan Slater and he’s a very capable, experienced, conscientious senior civil servant.“I’m afraid what’s happened is they’ve decided that someone has got to take the rap here, and it’s going to be the civil servant“I think the issue is the quality of the ministers. We can’t get into a situation where the buck is passed every time something goes wrong. It’s corrosive for the relationship between ministers and the civil service … Officials advise, ministers decide.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailMs Hayes said Whitehall was seeing “a very disturbing pattern of civil servants time and again taking the fall for the incompetence and failures of ministers”.The shadow Cabinet Office minister said a senior figure from outside the DFE should be brought it to look into the circumstances around the departures of Mr Slater and Ms Collier.“We certainly need more transparency and an investigation would be the right way to go about establishing whether there were any issues in both of these departments,” she told Today.“The way that the government would typically undertake an investigation within the civil service would be to appoint somebody from either from outside or from another civil service department to look at what what what had gone on. A summary sacking of the permanent secretary at the instruction of the prime minister is a very unusual way for the government to be meddling in the civil service.”Ms Hayes said: “If there are problems within civil service departments, there is due process for that. What's concerning about this is a constant meddling and summary sackings taking place to distract from the responsibility that Boris Johnson and his government bear for their lack of political leadership on these issues.“The chaos that we've seen around exam results has been a consequence of the political decisions that the government has made and it is really ministers who should be accountable for those decisions.“Gavin Williamson had two jobs - to get our schools back open for our children and to ensure that they received their grades fairly - and parents across the country have seen the chaos, the incompetence and indeed the distress which the government's handling of these issues has caused.“But this is a wider issue than simply about Gavin Williamson. We have a prime minister who promised a world-class education for every child, who said that the buck stops with him.“The reality is that he seems prepared to blame absolutely everybody but himself. Yesterday he was blaming an algorithm for the consequences of his own political decision-making.“So this is a much wider question than any one inidual and the buck stops with the prime minister.”Department for Education&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Power outages will last weeks to possibly months. Most of the area will be uninhabitable for weeks or months.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesLouisiana governor John Bel Edwards announced during his press conference on Wednesday that the state’s full National Guard had been deployed, and warned residents that they “only have a few hours to prepare and evacuate” before Laura hits its coast.He added: “Wherever you are by noon is where you’ll have to ride out the storm. Be smart and be safe.”Thousands evacuate as twin storms head for southern US statesAt its 11am ET update, the National Hurricane Centre warned that Laura could become “unsurvivable” for some areas of both Texas and Louisiana.The centre said that there will be an “unsurvivable storm surge with large and destructive waves will cause catastrophic damage from Sea Rim State Park, Texas, to Intracoastal City, Louisiana, including Calcasieu and Sabine Lakes.”It added that “only a few hours remain to protect life and property and all actions should be rushed to completion.” President Donald Trump tweeted about the storm on Wednesday, saying: “Hurricane Laura is a very dangerous and rapidly intensifying hurricane.“My administration remains fully engaged with state &amp local emergency managers to continue preparing and assisting the great people Texas, Louisiana, and Arkansas. story: People in England can use the Government tool to look up Covid- data for their local area.To visit the map website, click here.On mobile, enter your postcode, zoom in and click on the dot to reveal your local area. If blank, there are no cases. Click X to perform another search.An increase in testing across the country means that more cases of the virus may be being detected.This week residents in Manchester were told they would not be able to booze in parks during the bank holiday weekend in order to avoid a spike in cases.A fresh order has been put in place in the city centre which prohibits people from consuming alcohol in open spaces.It comes as the number of coronavirus cases in the city continues to be above the national average.A few weeks ago it doubled - and in parts of Oldham reached over  per ,.Yet it hasnt faced a full lockdown - with local leaders choosing instead to put in place less restrictive measures.The latest stats in Manchester show the measures appear to be working - with case numbers down mostly across the board.There are now  cases per , across the city, down from  last week.The postcode tool from Public Health England allows you to see how many cases are in your area as well as the surrounding areas.Crumpsall South has  cases, while Salford has . In Oldham, Werneth has  and Alexandra Park has .The figures, for England, will be published weekly at first with the aim of updating them daily.  Officials say the homes of iniduals who have tested positive for the coronavirus will not be identiable from the data.Public health professionals across each region will also be given positive test data and contact tracing figures every day.Tougher lockdown rules were reintroduced in parts of northern England on July  following an upsurge in Covid- cases.Around . million people in East Lancashire, West Yorkshire and Greater Manchester were told not to socialise with others in pubs, restaurants, cafes, shops or places of worship to curb the spread of the virus.On a national level the UKs coronavirus death toll rose by  yesterday, with another , people testing positive for the deadly bug.It means the total number of Covid- deaths recorded in Britain has now hit ,, with , positive tests.In England, nine people aged between  and  have died in hospital.All had underlying health conditions.Five of the deaths happened in the north west, with none recorded in the past  hours in either the south east or south west.Two more people died in Scotland, while one person lost their le in Wales.The latest tally refers to all fatalities in patients who died within  days of testing positive for Covid- - after a government shake up changed the way data is recorded.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions pose greater peril to pupils than covid
story: Dedicated classroom staff know the UK’s chief medical officers are dead right to say kids are more at risk of long-term harm from staying at home than from ing to school.They appreciate more than most how youngsters have been damaged by more than five months without learning, and that the most disadvantaged kids have suffered disproportionately.Their chief concern will be for the education of their pupils.Of course they want to be safe, and they want the children to be safe, but they don’t want to wait for impossible guarantees before ing to classrooms where the risk of infection is “exceptionally small”.That can’t be said of the union militants who see the Covid crisis as the perfect excuse to hold the Government to ransom.For them, pupils are just useful political pawns. The latest obstacles to learning come from Unison demanding more money for cleaning and masks for teachers before it will agree to theto school.Wouldn’t they — and flip-flopping Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer — enjoy the Government’s discomfortthey turn the start of the new term into another education fiasco Andchildren’s futures are blighted in the process, so what That’s a risk the militants seem only too happy to take.THE spate of illegal parties being broken up by police is shockingly predictable.Young adults happy to binge on dubious Class A drugs and toxic quantities of alcohol are hardly likely to bother too much about social distancing.Meanwhile, sensibly-controlled pubs and restaurants face ato lockdownCovid infections rise when the real culprits are those spreading the disease at unregulated gatherings.The deadly threat that partygoers pose to the elderly or vulnerable clearly doesn’t bother them when they selfishly suppose they won’t be badly affectedthey catch Covid.Raving idiots.THE BBC is set to drop crowd favourites Land of Hope and Glory and Rule, Britannia from the Last Night of The Proms in solidarity with Black Lives Matter.They think the perfect time to make the change is in the absence of a passionate audience who have cared deeply about these songs — symbols of our national pride — for more than  years.The trouble is, there are too many at the Beeb who just don’t like patriotism. title: banning anthems proms manipulates history
story: The BBC was last night facing a storm of anger over a proposal to drop Rule, Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory from the Last Night of the Proms.Finnish conductor Dalia Stasevska, , is said to be keen to modernise the show and cut its patriotic elements, while critics accuse the Beeb of pandering to the woke cancel culture and of ignoring the history of the anthems.Both the PM and his culture secretary Oliver Dowden involved themselves in the row, with the latter saying he believed that Rule, Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory are ‘highlights’ of the performance while adding: “Confident, forward-looking nations don’t erase their history, they add to it.”But then late in the day the BBC took the side of the woke cancel brigade in an extraordinary fudge.The orchestra will play the tunes of both songs — but nobody will sing the all-important words. Usually there is at least a soloist,not a full choir leading the audience, but of course this year the public seats in the hall will be empty because of the virus, and the voices on stage silenced.Now, the lyrics of both songs are pro-colonial. If you ban them from the Last Night of the Proms, ending a tradition going back decades, what consequences will that have Certainly, someone  years from now will say we shouldn’t have done that.It is the same argument for not taking down statues. If you remove statues because that person stands for something evil in their past, you are removing the deed too.Manipulating history only adds to mistrust among the black community.I would like to see the survey that says the public want these two songs taken out of the Proms programme, because it appears to me that the public hasn’t been consulted.Rule, Britannia! was written by Scottish poet James Thomson and he features on the famous Scott Monument in Edinburgh, near where I live.He is also commemorated in Westminster Abbey’s Poets’ Corner, next to William Shakespeare.If we say we must remove his words from the Proms, do we then remove the memorials too Rule, Britannia!, written and set to music in , was mentioned in James Joyce’s novel, Ulysses. It is part of my history and my culture. If we take it away, we take away part of my culture.It’s a song about the power structure at the time, and the arrogance and hypocrisy of Britain vowing to “never be slaves” while at the same time owning and benefiting from about , black chattel slaves in the West Indies who were called ‘property’.Of course, people are sensitive to its meaning, as well as Land Of Hope And Glory, the music of which was written by Edward Elgar.It doesn’t mean we should hide it.I personally don’t find the lyrics offensive because they are a true representation of the terrible truth at the time.If you take that away, then you are replacing history with a fairy story.There is also the possibility that it was written to show the evil of the time, rather than glorying it.The objection is that Rule, Britannia! is used by flag-waving “prommers” as a jubilant finale at the Proms.It is used in the wrong context, and that is part of the ignorance of our society of our history.It’s the same with Amazing Grace, which was written by a slaver of black people and is sung as a religious anthem.Recently, it was proposed that we should ban Swing Low, Sweet Chariot at rugby matches due to its link to slavery. That came to nothing.Instead of banning such songs or stripping away their lyrics, we need to educate people on the history of slavery, starting with putting it on the history curriculum.From speaking to people about slavery, the one constant reaction is always: “Why didn’t anyone tell us this before ”At the Proms, instead of taking the words away, we should put an explanation in the programme. We should tell people it’s about enslaving black people, making money from them, giving them a short le span and then compensating the slave owners when it was abolished because slaves were regarded as ‘property’.If they want to sing it after reading that, then fine, go ahead and sing it. But I bet they won’t sing it as joyfully as they might have done before.When I worked in research, I once had a lovely technician who worked for me. She looked after me so well, and she went to the Proms.If she knew the history of those two songs, being my friend, I doubt she would have sung along.It wasn’t her fault that she didn’t know the history.Those songs didn’t have a place in the Proms in the first place, they are there because of people’s ignorance. I would challenge anyone to know their meanings and still sing them in a frivolous capacity.But we shouldn’t be bothering ourselves about whether those songs should now be removed.What we should be bothering ourselves about is increasing the representation of black people who are the descendants of slaves. We should be concerning ourselves about making sure black people from the Windrush generation get compensation. And we should also be ensuring ourselves that every child is taught the history of slavery so that they can make their own minds up about whether to sing songs like these.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels ensure britain loses out
story: It is incredible after all this time to see Brussels still bent on ensuring that Britain somehow loses out, so fixated are they on deterring others from ­abandoning their club.They are still making patently unreasonable power grabs even their europhile fans struggle to defend. They still want newly-independent Britain to surrender full control of our fishing waters. To agree economic restrictions to prevent us undercutting them and keep us under their thumb.They simply must change the recordthey’re genuinely worried about the potential hardship of us trading on WTO terms — and them copping the blame. No objective person will fault Britain for sticking to its guns on principles so fundamental.Michel Barnier won’t get his way. He and those pulling his strings seem strangely unable to digest that the Theresa May regime is gone, that voters threw out the Remainer Parliament and installed committed Brexiteers instead.We do agree with Barnier that negotiations seem dead in the water and a “no deal” looks nailed on. But the blame for the lost jobs, there and here, will fall squarely at Brussels’ feet.They are wedded to impossible demands no sovereign nation could meet.NO ONE relishes nervous parents being punished for keeping kids off school. Butthat is the impetus they need as a last resort to conquer their Covid fear, so be it.Normal sanctions must apply once schools go back, as even Labour agrees they must. The five-month hiatus has been a disaster for many kids’ education and mental health and widened further the gap between state and private schools.It is vital that we also maintain calm perspectivethe virus does break out in some schools, as it inevitably will.Too many are terried simply by an uptick in cases. But they only really matterthey result in hospitalisations or deaths. And those are now extremely rare — even more so among the young.Medics are certain schools are safe.The damage done by keeping kids off will vastly exceed the tiny threat to their health.THEY say no good deed goes unpunished.That’s especially so when councils employ jobsworths who revel in their power to dish out fines.Imagine seeing thoughtful nurse Lydia Farrell giving away apples, then deciding she was littering. Real fly-tipping soared during lockdown. There are plenty of genuine offenders officials could target.But it’s always the low-hanging fruit.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leo mckinstry schools reopening militant teaching unions
story: After the long summer holidays, it signies hope at the chance of fresh beginnings and excitement at the prospect of change.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNext week, the new term will have greater meaning than ever for pupils, professionals and parents. At last, after an unprecedented lockdown of six months, all schools are due to re-open, representing a giant leap back towards normality. But the damage caused by the Coronavirus disruption has been severe.Many parents have been prevented from ing to work. Young people’s education has been badly undermined, especially because the quality of online learning has been so uneven. One study found that a fth of pupils had less than an hour’s instruction a day. Moreover, social activities and friendships – which are a vital part of growing up – have been heavily restricted.The exam chaos over the last fortnight was a fitting symbol of the vacuum created by the absence of proper schooling. No advanced society canwhen a vital sector like education is temporarily paralysed. That is why it is so important that the Government succeeds in its goal of seeing a fullto the classroom. As Boris Johnson put it at the weekend, “it is vital for pupils’ education. It is vital for their welfare. It’s vital for their physical and, indeed, mental well-being.”Given the Government’s mixed record on its management of the Covid crisis, this will be a big test. From the inadequate supply of protective gear to the botched imposition of quarantine rules, Ministers have got it badly wrong at times. They cannot afford another fiasco next week.But to do that, they will have to curtail the influence of militant teaching unions, which thrive in a climate of scare-mongering and grievance. Full of negativity, these hardened left-wing operators turn every pebble of dficulty into a giant boulder of obstruction. They are the abominable no men and women, the ultimate “can’t do” brigade.To overcome the unions’ capacity for trouble-making, reassurances about safety will be absolutely crucial. Most teachers are keen to go back to work, but they want to know schools will not be dangerous environments. That is why the recent upbeat advice from medical experts has been so welcome. It is clear from the Covid experience around the world that not only are children less likely to transmit the disease than any other group, but also that schools are safer than most other workplaces. Yesterday, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries pointed out that a child is more likely to be involved in a traffic accident or die from flu than to be harmed by Coronavirus.That message was also spelt out by her boss Chris Whitty, who said on Sunday that the damage to health caused by a continued schools lockdown is potentially greater than the impact of Covid. “The balance of risk is very strongly in favour of children going to school,” he declared, adding the chances of catching the disease “are incredibly small.” In fact, there is now hard evidence to prove this. Although the vast majority of schools were closed since March, over one million pupils – such as the children of essential workers – went back to the classroom in June. Yet a comprehensive study by Public Health England showed that in the subsequent weeks until the end of term, just  children and  staff tested positive for Covid- – and nearly all these infections occurred outside the school. There were hardly any cases of children passing on the disease to each other, or to their teachers. Other research from around the world has come to the same conclusion.But none of this seems to matter to the teaching unions, eager to exploit anxiety in pursuit of their anti-Tory agenda. These are the organisations which for decades have blocked every major reform of the education system and have defended every outdated working practice. With depressing inevitability, they have continually put their own narrow interests before the wider needs of pupils. They want the respect due to trained professionals but they frequently display the rebellious spirit of the permanent agitators. “Strike action is a very powerful tool,” said Amanda Martin, the President of the ,-strong National Education Unionin an interview with the Communist Morning Star newspaper in , adding, “I’ve run demos and rallies and worked with trade councils to bring everyone out and that’s brilliant.”Led by the NEU, the unions have brought the same attitude to the Coronavirus crisis. Instead of looking for solutions, they have endlessly exaggerated problems. One Whitehall insider says of Dr Mary Bousted, the £,-a-year joint general secretary of the NEU, “it’s all about the union, to hell with the teachers who want to get back into the classroom – let alone the children.” A left-wing radical, Bousted jokes that the word “strike” was one of the first she learnt as a child. Hers is not the voice of co-operation and enterprise, so it is hardly surprising that the Government has struggled to get schools reopened.In June, a planned majorwas thwarted by the unions, dealing a severe blow to Gavin Williamson’s credibility. One left-wing website gushed that the continued shutdown was due “to the hard work of NEU branch secretaries and rank and file militants galvanising the members.” In the months since, an alliance of unions – including Bousted’s NEU and Unite led by the notorious Merseyside militant Len McCluskey – have fought a y battle against a swt re-opening. Central to this effort at sabotage was a vast -point checklist of detailed questions which the Department for Education was told it had to answer. Dubbed by critics “a wreckers’ charter”, the list included queries such as “will lidded bins with double bagging be available in every classroom”, “will dedicated space be available for any breastfeeding women to express milk” and “has behaviour policy been reviewed to acknowledge the increased level of trauma and anxiety experienced by pupils ” Some Tories complained that the union was playing politics. Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Education Select Committee was amazed at the warped priorities: “It is incredible that not one of these nit-picking questions asks the most important thing of all – what’s best for the kids ”Even as September approaches, the whining and resistance has not ceased. “The unions need to stand firm and protect their members,” argues socialist teacher Martin Powell-Davies. In the latest ruse, the public sector outfit UNISON not only wants its members to wear masks in the classroom – something for which there is no scientic evidence of any need – but also to have extra funding for deep cleaning. “Schools need more money to pay for specially trained cleaners, rather than relying on other staff who are busy enough already,” says Jon Richards, UNISON’s head of education. The moan about over-stretched budgets is a favourite of the union movement but it is an empty accusation. The Government is pouring an extra £. billion into education, while this summer it was announced that teachers’ pay is to go up by an average of . per cent, a bigger increase than any other public sector workers received.But that did nothing to stop the combination of whingeing and shroud-waving. The mentality of the hardliners was embodied in a recent statement from the NEU’s far left “Education Solidarity Network” which set out a series of demands to “make sure safety comes first.” Among them were: “smaller class sizes to allow adequate physical distancing” arrangements “for rotas and home learning to be produced in consultation with parents” “local risk assessments to include staggered outdoor breaks, sanitising, provision of transparent coverings to enable access to lip reading and facial expression” and “weekly onsite testing of staff”. Above all, the Network called for extra funding “to implement these measures.” If there were any question of a risk to safety, the union should “prepare for a national strike ballot.”That was so typical. This lot seem to feel more comfortable on the picket line than in the classroom. The Solidary Network might be seen as extreme, but its carping outlook runs right through the unionYesterday, the NEU’s joint general secretary was bleating on the airwaves about the risks of new Covid spikes: “Staff, parents and pupils are being sorely let down by the government because of a lack of a Plan B and of ensuring robust track and trace is in place throughout the country. We believe the Government is negligent in the extreme.” The charge of negligence might be applied with more force to the NEU, whose hostile stance has made thesuch an exhausting obstacle course. The militants cannot be allowed to prevail next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we need to return high street jane moore
story: Having sex was virtually impossible, because by the time we’d removed them we had fallen asleep with exhaustion.Now, jeans come in all shapes and sizes and — hallelujah — streeeeeeetch where necessary to accommodate our lumps and bumps.However, it’s imperative to try before you buyyou want to find the perfect pair and, thanks to lockdown, I found myself shopping for jeans, and other clothes — online.The results prove why we simply mustn’t allow our struggling High Street clothes shops to vanish without trace.I’m usually a size , but am now sporting a bread-baby after lock- down so decided to play safe by ordering a size bigger. Pictured is, apparently, a pair of “size ” jeans from online giant Asosin front of my old size sI couldn’t get them up one leg and, quite frankly, Kate Moss would struggle too. So they’re going back.Then a beguiling ad for summer dresses popped up on my Instagram account and I clicked through to a site called “Cinderear” showing a wide range of very pretty frocks on tanned and shapely models.I ordered what was described as a “Printed Folding Holiday Swing Dress” in what looked like an airy cotton, cinched in at the waist with a brown leather belt. The colour was described as apricot.What arrived — several weeks later — was a beyond-hideous sartorial aberration that was “Made in China” , out of a paper-thin polyester that would make me think twice about standing near a naked flame.What’s more, the colour was more camel and blue than “apricot”, it swamped me, and the brown belt in the photo was nowhere to be seen.It cost me  — approx £ — and the s policy is so ­unintelligible that it’s not worth the bother. More fool me.Buying a bookshelf or bog brush online is fine, but clothes is another matter. I like to feel the fabric and see the fit.So a couple of weeks ago, I masked up and ventured out on a shopping trip to West London’s vast Westfield where I felt like a ­Hollywood superstar having a ­personal shopping experience. It was am on a Monday morning and virtually empty.Little wonder when the ­government guidance says retailers must “discourage customers from handling products while browsing, and keep fitting rooms closed”.One store let me try on a dress then sanitised the cubicle afterwards, another told me thatI tried something on they would have to then take it off display for  hours.In LK Bennett, the fitting rooms were closed and I askedI could try on a blouse over my clothes, just to seeit actually fits. No, they said, you have to buy the item, take it home to try it on, then bring it backit doesn’t fit. Needless to say, I ed home empty-handed.So,our High Street clothes shops are to survive the pandemic, two things need to happen.Unless classed as vulnerable, those of us who actually enjoy clothes ­shopping need to get back out there as soon as possible and actively support them. And the Government needs to relax its strict rules and let retailers and shoppers take inidual responsibility for what happens in store.If I have to wear a mask and gloves to try on a pair of jeans in a cubicle, then I’m happy to do so. I’ll even wipe it down afterwards with my newly repurposed “apricot” dress.SPORTED by the likes of Chris Waddle back in the day, the mullet is apparently enjoying a resurgence during the pandemic.Oh dear. Now barbers have reopened, let’s hope the trend proves short-lived for the naff hairdo that was once described in a dictionary as: “Short at the front, long at the back and ridiculous all round.”FORMER Ukip leader Henry Bolton became embroiled in a scandal after leaving his third we for the charms of party supporter Jo Marney.Now, three years on, that relationship is also over. The reasons why are unclear, but Ms Marney, , says that aside from going on long walks and cosying up in country pubs, they “argued about the finer points of EU legislation”.Ah yes, that should do it.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not feature in TV drama The Crown because there’s not “enough distance” from their story, says the show’s creator Peter Morgan.Also, their le is so outlandish that the series would fall under the category of reality show rather than drama.VINNIE JONES – the “hardman” of football – is seeing a psychologist three times a week after losing we Tanya to cancer.“I would recommend going to see a psychologist  per cent,” he says.“You’re not lying down on a couch asyou’re some lunatic or serial killer. Blokes don’t want to talk about it.“They’ll talk about the girl they slept with last night but won’t go and talk to a doctor about how they’re feeling.”He’s right, and with men accounting for  per cent of all suicides in the UK, it’s never been more important for men like Vinnie to convey that showing vulnerability isn’t a weakness – it’s an admirable strength.CLAUDIA SCHIFFER turned  on tuesday and says she has “never felt more confident or happy”.She adds that she embraces “now” and: “I don’t try to look or feel younger.”She doesn’t need to really, does she ELECTRIC car maker Tesla is developing a sensor that will detecta child has been left unattended in a hot car.Don’t we have those already They’re called parents.LIFE’S precious silences are few and far between. And when you’re PM, one can imagine they are practically non-existent.Particularly as, the ­second you step into the privacy of your own home, there’s a baby with no “on-off” switch.So Boris’s holiday tent – pitched a hundred yards away from his rented cottage on the Scottish coastline – intrigues me. Was it an escape for him alone to snatch a few hours of quiet reflection Or was it a chance for him and Carrie to have noisy sex away from the baby and ever-present bodyguards THE top dream jobs for school leavers are app or games developer and social media influencer.If kids don’t get back to school pronto, that’s all they’ll be able to do.NO ONE begrudges ­politicians a holiday – ­particularly during a ­parliamentary recess.But when you’re an Education minister, you have one job – to be around when the ordure inevitably hits the fan over A-level results being randomly downgraded by an algorithm.Yet not only did Gillian Keegan book a trip abroad, she actually posted a photo from the French Alps on results day – when countless students saw their future plans evaporate. Duh.She also decided to stay there after the quarantine rules came into force – meaning she will have to self-isolate at home for a fortnight on her .But hey ho she’s a taxpayer-funded civil servant so she’s comfortablein the knowledge that, unlike the self-employed, she won’t be losing any pay.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc does not represent britain
story: It is clear from its news, its commentary, its dramas and its dismal, lazy comedy that it despises the voting majority which — to the out-of-touch corporation’s disbelief — repeatedly backed both Brexit and the Tories.Its decision now to censor Rule, ­Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory ought to be the last straw.Boris Johnson has rightly joined many others in condemning it. And though it is not for the PM to decide the BBC’s output, his Government can and should end its publicly funded financial model.The Beeb could turn this around. It just doesn’t want to. It dislikes much about Britain and is ashamed of our past.Its woke staff are interested only in causes and ideas beloved of middle-class metropolitan Remainer graduates like them. Mainstream views shared by the ordinary majority, older Conservative voters in particular, are held in contemptthey are considered at all.So Tories, who won a huge election mandate only months ago, are treated with cynical disdain. Meanwhile ­left-wing activists are routinely given s on news programmes where they masquerade as “ordinary people” or even Newsnight journalists.The BBC has destroyed the case for its licence fee. It’s time the Government stopped griping about it and took action.THE U-turn on wearing Covid masks in schools is an own-goal.For months the Government, backed by its Sage scientists and a wealth of international evidence, assured parents it is entirely safe to start the new term.How so,kids in some areas now ­suddenly need masks — and Heads where will be able to bring them in too We don’t believe they are scientically necessary in schools at all, given how lightly the virus affects children and how rarely they spread it to teachers.All they will do is ramp up fear among pupils and over-anxious parents while causing teachers a discipline nightmare.And why the about-face, hours after denying masks would be needed in schools  Because Scotland brought them in  Because the WHO changed its tune  Because unions might have used their absence as a new wrecking tactic  None of those is a decent motive. Either the Government believes masks are medically essential in schools or, like its top advisers, it doesn’t. title: rod liddle bbc rule britannia
story: All those ghastly people waving their Union Jacks. Singing Land of Hope and Glory and Rule, Britannia!. Nasty Little Englanders who probably voted for Brexit. It’s the one night of the year when the BBC’s left wing bias is dropped for an hour or two. And the licence-payer for once gets what they want. An evening of enjoyable, uplting patriotism.The BBC holds Middle England in utter contempt – and has done so for a long while. It cannot tolerate anything which doesn’t fit into its woke agenda. title: jacob blake riots hunt vigilante kyle rittenhouse kenosha
story: Kyle Rittenhouse, , was arrested after a gunman was filmed firing his AR--style rle at activists and brazenly walking past cops.The complaint stated that the teen says the teenager fled the state of Wisconsin with the intent to avoid prosecution for that offense.Two activists were killed during the alleged shooting spree, with one of the victims being named on social media as Anthony Huber, while a third man was shot in the arm.Wisconsin Attorney General Josh Kaul said: The violence and destruction that took place in Kenosha last night was despicable.While the two people who were killed and the person who was injured by gunfire have not yet been identied, we are thinking of their destroyed futures and their friends and families that must live with this overwhelming grief.Rittenhouses arrest came after:The Milmaukee Journal Sentinel noted that based on Wisconsin law, Rittenhouse is being charged as an adult.Rittenhouse was allegedly allowed to walk past a swarm of police with his hands up and holding his semi-automatic rle.The teen, from Antioch, Illinois, was today arrested and charged with first degree intentional homicide.Rittenhouse was interviewed before two activists were killed during the alleged shooting spree, with one of the victims being named on social media as Anthony Huber.He told a Daily Caller journalist people are getting injured as protesters decried the police shooting of Jacob Blake.The reporter noted that the business they stood outside of had been lit on fire the previous night as riots raged.Our job is protect this business, Rittenhouse said, standing outside of the boarded up building. And part of my job is to also help people.If theres somebody hurt, Im running into harms way and thats why I have my rle, to protect myself obviously.Protesters were heard screaming early this morning in Kenosha, Wisconsin as the shots were fired.Shocking footage shows a man being chased by demonstrators after he had already allegedly shot someone in the stomach a few blocks away, TMZ reported.The man in the video can be seen falling as hes chased before firing his gun, fatally hitting two people.As police arrive, the gun-slinging man they suspect to be Rittenhouse puts his hands up in the air and the cops pass him.The lead up to the fatal shooting isnt clear but police think it may have resulted from a gas station cojnflict.Cops said self-styled militias were defending local businesses from looters but the sherf didnt confirm that the gunman was one of the armed citizens patrolling the streets.Koerri Elijah told Insider that the teenager, later identied as Rittenhouse by cops, appeared to be on edge before he ran past him and shots rang out.I noticed him the entire time. He didnt seem like he was there with anyone, Elijah said. He was armed. He didnt seem like he was a threat, but I thought maybe I should keep an eye on him.Hours before he was identied as a suspect, social media sleuths named the teen boy and posted his picture online.Last night, the first shots were fired just after midnight, as a group of protesters faced off police in riot trucks on Sheridan Road.People were then seen chasing the man before another round of rapid-fire shots were heard.People on the streets were seen dragging the injured to the side of the road before performing CPR.After being shot in the head, a protester was loaded into the back of an SUV and rushed to a nearby hospital.Shocking pictures emerged of people tending to a wounded person during the vicious clashes.Other residents attempting to protect local businesses as fires raged throughout the city.Devin Scott, , told the Chicago Tribune he was in a group chanting Black Lives Matter when the gunfire began and that he tried unsuccessfully to revive one of the victims.He told the Tribune: This guy with this huge gun runs by us in the middle of the street and people are yelling, He shot someone! He shot someone!And everyone is trying to fight the guy, chasing him, and then he started shooting again.Scott said he hit the ground during the next burst of gunfire, then tried to aid a person who was lying prone in the street.He added: I was cradling him in my arms. I was trying to keep this kid alive and he wasnt moving or nothing. He was just laying there.Carol Badoni, from Burlington, Wisonsin, spoke to the girlfriend of one of the victims, she said his name was Ben Wis.Carol, , said: “He definitely was not breathing,”“His eyes were rolled back in his head. There was no pulse.”But she added that she saw no blood, before cops arrived and took Ben to hospital.In another clip, a man was seen removing his top to help another victim of the shooting.Meanwhile, other protests erupted across the country in response to the shooting.Police in Portland, Oregon, also declared a gathering of hundreds of anti-racism protesters outside City Hall as a riot, ordering the crowd to disperse or face arrest.People at the Kenosha protest were heard shouting: Theres people getting shot everywhere.Kenosha has been riddled with violence, looting, criminal damage and fires in response to the death of Jacob Blake, a -year-old black man who was shot by police.Blake was shot several times in the back by police as he stepped into his car.His horried children were in the car at the time and would have seen the attack.On Tuesday, Blakes family confirmed that he is still alive but in a critical condition and is paralyzed.Jacob Blake Sr. said: They shot my son seven times. Seven times. Like he didnt matter. But my son matters. Hes a human being and he matters.While his family have pleaded for peaceful protests, they have hit out at police, saying they systematically brutalize black peoplePolice attempted to boarder off Kenosha after Monday nights protests led to buildings being set on fire and stores looted.Seven exit ramps were closed from Interstate- from the Illinois border to Racine, Wis. which is about  minutes north of Kenosha.In downtown Kenosha, a huge crowd of protesters gathered around the barrier at Kenosha County Courthouse.One protester, Nathan, , who didnt want to give his full name said: A lot of fear in the air because of threats to protesters.“I worry a lot about the misinformation,” he said after explaining he didnt think national movement to bring greater police accountability will lead to real change.Although, he said locally, his city will never be the same.“It’s hard to see now, but it will be a positive thing,” he said of the protests.“It’ll bring Kenosha back together. Kenosha has always been a resilient place. It’ll continue to happen.”Thousands joined the protest on Tuesday, with some carrying handguns, AR- rles, knives and dressed in military flak jackets.Dennis, , from Racine, was carrying a pistol he claimed was for protection for himself and other protesters.“Nothing is going to change,” he said, hanging back from the crowd. “This is all for nothing.”A group of the protesters began violently shaking the barriers and launched fireworks at the police officers.Cops were seen firing tear gas pellets and rubber bullets into the crowd.One officer was heard shouting: Yall better have gas masks on! Get ready!Before another cop was seen opening the hatch of the vehicle and throwing the canister in their direction.Another man was heard shouting: F**king p**sies!By pm  policwe officers dressed in riot gear formed a chain across the park nearby the court house.There were  fires associated with the unrest, with  businesses destroyed or damaged along with an unknown number of residences, Kenosha Fire Chief Charles Leipzig told the Kenosha News.On Tuesday, President Donald Trump urged Wisconsin officials to call in the National Guard to quell the unrest, despite troops already being on the ground.Governor should call in the National Guard in Wisconsin. Trump tweeted.On Monday, residents with firearms were seen standing outside local businesses in a bid to stop the looting and arson.One of the armed men in the footage taken Monday night says: Theyre destroying their own neighborhood. story: Now a team of researchers say they have come up with a tool that can analyse dreams to reveal the truth behind their meaning.Experts from the Nokia Bell Labs in Cambridge have created a technique using computers to look at dreams called Natural Language Processing.It looks for nouns to identy people, animals, and fictional characters, as well as verbs to classy interactions - as either friendly or aggressive.Scientists used their code to analyse , dream reports from Dreambank, the largest public repository of dreams. Among those whose dreams were analysed included an artist, a blind person, a school girl, a war veteran and a cross-dressing businessman.The results were compared with assessments by psychiatrists and showed that dreams are a continuation of what happens in every day le.The researchers said: “Our results suggest that it is possible to quanty important aspects of dreams, making it possible to build technologies that bridge the current gap between real le and dreaming.”Dr Luca Aiello, one of the authors of a study published in the Royal Society Open Science journal, told i: “We are not trying to replace the experts, but we are trying to automate part of this process to make it easier for them.“At large scale, you might imagine that events like the Covid- pandemic are most likely affecting how people feel and affecting their dreams.“If most people were to share those dreams we could monitor over the dferent weeks of the pandemic, how people feel about it. story: Experts at Cambridge University have developed a vaccine for Covid- that would be administered to people through the skin via a jet of air.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHuman trials are set to start in the autumn and the government will fund the first human trial to the tune of £. million.The vaccine is being developed by DIOSynVax, a company founded by Professor Jonathan Heeney, who is the head of viral zoonotics at Cambridge University, along with University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust.He said the goal is to “make a coronavirus vaccine that will protect us not only from this pandemic, but the next one”.The vaccine will use a device which is already used for some cancer treatments.Experts say that pushing skin cells using air can induce finely tuned responses in comparison to other vaccines.Most vaccines that are currently being developed work by exposing people to a “spike protein” which the virus uses to connect with human cells.In order to develop the new vaccine the team at Cambridge analysed hundreds of coronaviruses - including those found in bats.They then used their results to build a library of antigens which mimic the molecules on coronaviruses.The experts say that the aim of this is to find shared antigens between dferent coronavirus, which could mean that one jab could protect against all of them.Prof Heeney said: “We’re looking for crucial pieces of the virus that we can use to direct the immune response in the right direction. Ultimately we aim to make a vaccine that will not only protect from Sars-CoV-, but other related coronaviruses that may spill over from animals to humans.”  He added that manufacturing of the vaccine should be cheap and said that it does not need to be refrigerated.This means that the vaccine will also be accessible to people in hotter countries.Prof Heeney said it’s unlikely that the new vaccine will trigger a bad immune response.The first trials will take place at the National Institute for Health Research Southampton Clinical Research Facility at University Hospital Southampton.Director of the facility, Professor Saul Faust said: “It is critical that dferent vaccine technologies are tested as at this stage no one can be sure which type of vaccine will produce the best and most long-lived immune responses.”It comes just days after Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty said he would be surpriseda vaccine was available before .The daily increase in fatalities and cases across the UK has continued to slow this month however health authorities are on high alert for any spike in the deadly bug.Prof Whitty today said he would be delighteda vaccine came early.But the CMO said: I’d be quite surprisedwe had a highly effective vaccine ready for mass use in a large percentage of the population before the end of winter, certainly before this side of Christmas.”He added: I think it is unlikely we will have a vaccine that is highly effective and ready to deploy at scale this winter meaning  .I think there is a reasonable chance that we will have vaccines, not a certainty, in the period before the following winter of  .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Manaus, in the Amazon, has seen a dramatic fall in coronavirus cases and deaths since hitting , fatalities.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe city of two million people was once one of the worlds hardest-hit, with drone images taken in April showing mass graves and burials occurring at five times their normal rate. But last week, Manaus saw its “excess deaths” drop to almost zero - as tests suggested that around  per cent of the city’s population had been infected with the bug. Jarbas Barbosa da Silva, assistant director of the Pan American Health Organisation, told The Washington Post: “The hypothesis — and this is just a hypothesis — is that the peak we had in Manaus was very strong, and there was such widespread community transmission that it may have produced some kind of collective immunity”.Mr Barbosa said that the fall in cases suggested a “natural dynamic”, rather than the effect of lockdown or other preventative measures. However, it is not confirmed whether the fall in cases and deaths could also be due to underreporting in the area.Herd immunity refers to a population’s resistance to the spread of a contagious disease built up through immunity from infection or vaccination.Sweden controversially opted against a lockdown in favour of a herd immunity policy set out by state epidemiologist Anders Tegnell. But the policy proved controversial, leading to the worlds sixth highest per capita death rate - with care homes hit particularly badly.New research, reported by The Times, showed that levels of combined T-cell and antibody immunity could be more than  per cent. For ages, this government insisted that they would not have to do so. Now they’ve changed their minds. Face masks and grouped in “bubbles”. Never mind that there has been no recorded case of a schoolkid passing on the virus to a teacher.Never mind that our economy needs the schools fully open with a proper, normal, timetable, so people can get back to work.After six months of no lessons , the kids now have to endure insufferable conditions at school.This is because Boris and the rest have proved utterly incapable of standing up to the teaching unions .Other U-turns have involved the wearing of masks in shops, the usefulness of masks in general, whether there’s any point in closing our borders, the schools due to re-open in June, the scrapping of an expensive track and trace system, the re-grading of GCSEs and A levels . . . oh lordy, the list goes on and on.Sometimes the U-turn appears only a day after the original decision.Sometimes we have to wait a week or so. But come they surely do, a long parade of staggering ineptitude. In fact, I think even Frank Spencer would have been more decisive. Maybe the right comparison is with Benny from Crossroads. Yes, it’s my age again. For those who don’t know, Benny was a cast-iron moron.We know that dealing with this horrible pandemic can’t have been easy. We know Boris has had a dficult year.But the utter lack of planning and resolve has been astonishing. Slow to take the virus seriously, bizarrely refusing to close our airports at the peak of the outbreak, hopelessly lost over track and trace and what do with our poor kids.This has been mismanagement on an almost heroic level. My guess is that Boris will not survive as Prime Minister: His party will get shot of him when the opportunity arises. Because here’s the crucial, damaging question.Could Jeremy Corbyn have handled this crisis any worse I DON’T think those smug monkeys at the BBC realised the fury they would unleash when they banned singing our favourite anthems at The Last Night Of The Proms.A petition reached , names in just  hours.And Dame Vera Lynn is suddenly at No in the iTunes chart with Land Of Hope And Glory.The BBC apparently agreed with the Finnish conductor, Dalia Stasevska, that the “jingoistic” words of Land Of Hope And Glory and Rule Britannia would not be heard this year.I wonder what convinced Ms Stasevska to agree to conduct an evening of patriotic songs when she hates patriotic songs Money, you would guess. Meanwhile another BBC bureaucrat, Cat Lewis, likened singing the songs to Nazis singing about gas chambers.Silly woman. The BBC – its entire staff – has no understanding of the British people. It despises them. Support for the corporation is at an all-time low. And yet the BBC is still up to its tricks. Pulling off the unusual feat of being already in a coffin, but reaching out somehow to hammer more nails into its own lid.A TEAM of British scientists has been studying dreams and what they mean.And they’ve discovered they mean sod all. They are just a continuation of memories from the previous day.Other recent studies showed the same thing. So,you dream you’re flying around your house with some bats, it means you were probably thinking about bats when you were awake.It doesn’t mean you’re neurotic or sexually repressed. So – that’s all the work of Sigmund Freud in the bin. It can go in a black bin liner along with the idiocies put forward by that other drongo of the th Century, Karl Marx. But given that we know all this, why are there still psychoanalysts plying their trade  Is it just to give Britain’s couch-makers plenty of work ANOTHER stupid, virtue-signalling British firm has run into trouble.Avanti West Coast made a big fuss about its new “pride train”, which runs from London to Manchester.The engine is painted in the colours of the LGBT rainbow flag.And it has the word “Pride” written in big letters – just in case anyone doesn’t get the message. There have been thousands of angry comments on social media.My favourite was from John James McGivern: “As a gay man, I don’t want a ‘pride train’, I just want to get on a train that runs on time like everyone .” Quite. Well said.Every time companies pull a stunt like this, the nation cringes.I don’t want a bloody voucher. You cancel the train I’m booked on, then refund the ticket.So I complain to them and they say nothing we can do.So I complain some more and tell them they’re acting illegally.Bingo – money back! I know a lot of people have had similar problems with airlines cancelling their flights and offering “vouchers”.It pays to pester these buggers. Pester and pester until they give in.POOR old slabhead, then. Manchester United’s Harry Maguire found himself uttering the most stupid words in the English language.“Do you know who I am ” And then explained to the Greek police officers who had arrested him that he was “very rich”. Then he tried to bribe them.⚠️Click here for the latest news on Harry MaguireGod help us all.I have always admired Maguire’s heading ability.It now seems to me that he gets so much force behind each header because he has reinforced concrete between his ears. Footballers are not renowned for being terribly bright.But Maguire has lowered the bar still further.One of the problems is the one to which the footballer alluded. He has too much money. So much that he doesn’t know what to do with it.And as a result is completely insulated from the real world. And when he does venture out into the real world it is to be continually abused by halfwits who do not like the club he plays for.Say sorry to the Greeks, Harry. And then shut up and play football.Andlouts give you abuse in the street, just smile at them.CHILDREN from working families were much better behaved during lockdown, according to a study from three British universities.I know that will come as news to some of you.A lot of kids seemed to be climbing the walls out of sheer boredom. But the researchers found that the kids had fewer tantrums. And their concentration improved, too.Maybe we should have a lockdown every year.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ex education chiefs call to reopen schools
story: Tories Damian Hinds, Justine Greening and Kenneth Baker, Labour’s David Blunkett and Lib Dem David Laws all united.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey told The Sun there is a “desperate need” to reopen schools and they warned: “The future of our country depends on it.” Any longer out of the classroom risks causing untold damage to kids’ studies, health and wellbeing, they added.Together, their time in charge of England’s schools spanned four decades.Ex-Education Secretary Lord Blunkett, , said: “Getting schools reopened is absolutely fundamental to everything that we stand for.“We send children to school for a purpose — and that is because their very future and the future of our ­country depends on it.”The country’s schools, colleges and nurseries closed for most kids in March as coronavirus swept the country.The national schools shutdown was the first in English history and a string of alarming reports found it has ­massively widened the education gap between rich and poor. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised to get all of England’s pupils back to class full- time next week.The ex-schools supremos warned that No cannot fail in this test.Lord Baker,  — who was Education Secretary under Margaret Thatcher — said that the Covid education crisis could be as bad as the recession.He said: “This is the Prime Minister’s biggest challenge now, getting all children back to school.“You will find that some parents are anxious, and that some children won’t want to go back — but we have got to get them into the routine of schools.“Once you lose out on a stage of your schooling like this, you may end up losing out for ever.“It affects a child’s entire future. It is very, very important and it must happen.” Ms Greening, , who was Education Secretary under Theresa May, said the past six months have been “hugely damaging” for kids.She said: “Parents have done their level best home-schooling but we urgently need schools open safely so children can get back to full-time education. We also need a catch-up plan to help them recover lost ground.”Mr Hinds, , Education Secretary until July last year, said: “Kids desperately need to get back to school.“In the immediate term, mental and physical health are supported by the routine of going to school, interacting with friends and teachers and accessing purposeful activity.”Mr Laws, , Schools Minister during the Coalition, said: “Given the huge learning loss during lockdown, particularly for the poorest children, it’s vital we do everything we can to ensure a fullto school next week, provided this is supported by the health advice.”It is a crucial test for Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, who is clinging on to his job by a thread in the wake of humiliating U-turns on mask wearing in schools and A-level results.Fuming Tory MPs have urged No to sack himhe fails to get schools reopened on time.Perhaps an adult wearing a mask in a lab makes them safer but I believe children in a school will be less safe with masks. Do we really imagine a world where our teenagers turn up every day to school with a freshly washed mask which they will wear without issue throughout the day  They will swap their masks, ping them, lick them, spit in them and pass them around for fun. They will shout obscenities through them, bully each other over not having the right type, wear them wrong and they will encourage them to touch their faces dozens of times a day.And teachers need to be able to see the mouths of their charges to hold them to account for chatting, swearing and the like. Mask them up and teachers won’t have a clue who said it. Eventually you have chaos in the classroom. Hand-washing, social-distancing as much as one can and keeping children in bubbles is the way to go. Headteachers should not be swayed by how things appear and rather look seriously at how things really are.Schools in Wales are also reopening next week, while they have been open for a fortnight already in Scotland.All of the UK’s chief medical officers have declared that it is safe for children toto school.On a visit to a school in Leicestershire today, Mr Johnson said: “This is an absolutely invaluable time for them — they must get back into school.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: A fresh order has been put in place in the city centre due to the pandemic which will stop people from consuming alcohol in open spaces.Events due to take place have also had to be cancelled thanks to the pandemic, but people have been allowed to meet up outside.Groups of six from up to two households are allowed to meet outdoors, but across the city people arent supposed to meet up inside at all.It comes as the number of coronavirus cases in the city continues to be above the national average.A few weeks ago it doubled - and in parts of Oldham reached over  per ,.Yet it hasnt faced a full lockdown - with local leaders choosing instead to put in place less restrictive measures.The latest stats in Manchester show the measures appear to be working - with case numbers down mostly across the board.There are now  cases per , across the city, down from  last week.But Bury and Wigan, have seen more cases reported.Health officials think the virus is being spread from household to household, rather than through workplaces.It came as police continued to get calls about illegal raves and parties taking place across the country - despite the pandemic.Manchester, Birmingham and other major cities have all seen cops shut down gatherings.People attending can be fined £ - and those who host the bashes will be able to face a £, fine too.Greater Manchester police confirmed the news today.Inspector Jonathan Shilvock said: Due to this years events being cancelled, and for the fear of the effect it has on public health, there is a Public Space Protection Order in place in Manchester city centre which prohibits the consumption of alcohol in a non-licensed public place and will be enforceable this weekend by Greater Manchester Police.They urged everyone to think of friends and family before breaking rules this weekend.A spokesperson added: Were doing all we can to make sure legislation is complied with to keep everyone safe.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The revelation is a huge blow for the Prime Minister, who has been leading a push for people to get back to their officesthey can to save the economy.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesDowning Street wants the civil service to lead by example and help prop up the bars, cafes and other businesses that continue to be left empty.Thousands of businesses in city centres are still struggling to make ends meet as many stay at home over fears of catching the virus. And Dave Penman, head of the FDA union which represents senior civil servants, told the Financial Times that the government had realised it was dficult to persuade some officials toto the office following a series of local outbreaks.He said: “In most [government] departments the numbers [of civil servants ing to the office] are steadily going up but it’s not going to be huge numbers, it’s not going to be a majority [by the end of the year], we’ll probably get to  or  per cent over time.The UKs largest civil service trade union, the Public and Commercial Services Unionhas also poured cold water on the plans for a , saying the move would risk health and safety.But MPs have called on firms to get back to the office to help the nation recover.Ben Everitt, the MP for Milton Keynes North, said: With the kids going back to school it’s now time to get our offices and businesses bouncing back. This shouldnapost be necessary to say, because we all had history lessons and we were awake for some of them. But Britannia has never ruled the waves.We had officially-approved pirates who stole gold from the Spanish and started the slave trade. We had glorious navies that had a habit of sinking, we dodged U-boats, we provided the first circumnavigation of the globe, and the first man to do it alone. But we also had a king who told the waves to go away, and collective amnesia about the point he was trying to make.King Cnut did not get his feet wet in the th century just so he could be a cipher for a swearword on Twitter , years later. He tried to rule the waves in order to prove that, despite being a warrior king with  North Sea countries beneath his heel, waves do their own thing. Britannia was around before him, was revived as a bit of Elizabethan militarist propaganda, and in  got nicked by a prince who wanted a song to impress his dad, George II. At the time, our ruling of the waves was centred on what became known as the War of Jenkinsapos Ear, about slave trading rights. We lost. The Prime Minister, who likes to give the impression he knows more history than anyone , must know that Rule Britannia is a silly song. He must, surely, realise that these islands did not pop up from an azure main, has noangels, and especially that not only has it got one of the smallest navies of all time, but is about to have a cavalry without any tanks.He probably does think, as verse  does, that foreign nations must, in their turn, to tyrants fall, that we are the envy of them all and our cities shall with commerce shine as verse  proclaims. But itaposs bollocks. Mainly because anything you tell George II in  to keep him happy is bound to be, but also because Boris Johnson has put this country on a course to - let me just check this official government document - ah yes, complete economic and social meltdown. That is no reason for the PM not to make a fuss about the BBC being too wet to let us sing a jaunty tune. Because otherwise we might notice that Dominic Cummings has given £m in uncontested government contracts to his mates, that a misogynist Aussie with no business experience has been put in charge of our Brexit trade deals, and that heaposs u-turned so often the PM is technically doing doughnuts in Downing Street. Of all the things that should be making anyone, of any political bent or age or race, steaming mad today, the fact that an empty Albert Hall will not be shaken to the rafters by , people who only know the chorus anyway is the very least of them.Get angry about Cummings gting a total of £m in contracts to colleagues and friends to find out what the public think of the government, when he could ask his neighbours for free.Fret, why donapost you, about how a shadowy group of Right-wing conspiracy theorists who claim to be protecting children marched on Buckingham Palace to shout paedophile! at Prince Andrew, despite the fact not a single Royal was in residence and the crimes he is accused of, while heinous, do not include paedophilia. Such stupidity is expected, by Brits, in other countries - itaposs pretty worrying to see it manest in The Mall.Or you could be infuriated by shame at the country being run by people who genuinely believe the Board of Trade should be graced by a man of without business experience, but who sent refugee children to sicken and starve on a Pacic island and whose reputation, such as it is, was savaged in the most devastating political speech Australia has ever witnessed.  Second thoughts, letaposs not. Merely boiling with fury does not seem to change much. If it did, Piers Morgan would be God.Letaposs ask ourselves, instead, whether to mask, or not to mask that is the question. Whether apostis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of these absolute cockwhistles, or to take arms against a sea of troublesome twits, and by opposing, end them.Letaposs remind ourselves that weaposre arguing about masks only because incompetents who have spent decades arguing about bendy bananas and how many children theyaposre responsible for are now in charge of keeping us safe, and are arguing about that, too. The question to ask is whether you put up with all this, or arm yourself with the knowledge and facts they would rather you didnapost have. Like the background to Rule Britannia, the lyrics you never knew, and wondering how it is that this country has forgotten it started, and ended, slavery fought just, and unjust, wars honoured, and destroyed, countless wrongaposuns. History will tell you that Britain is not all bad, and not all good. Richard the Lionheart was a magnicent warrior, and brutal Islamophobe and anti-Semite. Elizabeth I was feted as a great beauty, and ended her days a crone with blackened teeth. Queen Victoria was thick as mince, Bazalgetteaposs sewer and WT Steadaposs th century sensationalist journalism did more to improve public health than any -word slogans, and our last  Prime Ministers have been an ever-decreasing circle of ineptitude who have deprived this nation of everything it still had that was great. Common sense went out the window with austerity. Historical perspective, the ability to see the past and future and our place in it, was pissed up the wall in the Brexit referendum. And irony, Iaposm afraid, is sobbing quietly in a little ball under Nicola Sturgeonaposs Holyrood throne, from whence she is ruling the entire United Kingdom. All outrage aside,there is something that has been a constant in the UK down the centuries it is a substantial majority of people who look at those strutting about the national stage and ignore them. Itaposs how the monarchy, and any number of governments, has survived.

story: NewsGovernment publishes G guide to combat myths and unfounded conspiracy theories"Quack" theories claim the super-fast mobile network is responsible for any number of health issues, including CoronavirusShareByPatrick DalyMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  AUG News " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
